import { Image } from "astro:assets";
import Demo from "@components/Demo.astro";
import PageSwitcher from "@components/PageSwitcher.astro";
import Imports from "@components/examples/badge/Imports.astro";
import badgeTypes from "@assets/badge-types.png";

<Imports />
<PageSwitcher />

## Explanation of badge styles

The following badge styles have been implemented based on the VSCode UI:

1. Default style
2. Activity bar counter
3. Counter
4. Tab bar counter

<Image
  src={badgeTypes}
  alt="Visual explanation of various badge styles"
/>

## Default style

<Demo>
  <vscode-badge>308 Settings Found</vscode-badge>
  <Fragment slot="html">
    ```html
    <vscode-badge>308 Settings Found</vscode-badge>
    ```
  </Fragment>
</Demo>

## Counter

<Demo>
  <vscode-badge variant="counter">42</vscode-badge>
  <Fragment slot="html">
    ```html
    <vscode-badge variant="counter">42</vscode-badge>
    ```
  </Fragment>
</Demo>

## Activity bar counter

<Demo>
  <vscode-badge variant="activity-bar-counter">42</vscode-badge>
  <Fragment slot="html">
    ```html
    <vscode-badge variant="activity-bar-counter">42</vscode-badge>
    ```
  </Fragment>
</Demo>

## Tab header counter

<Demo>
  <vscode-badge variant="tab-header-counter">42</vscode-badge>
  <Fragment slot="html">
    ```html
    <vscode-badge variant="tab-header-counter">42</vscode-badge>
    ```
  </Fragment>
</Demo>

<Imports />
<PageSwitcher />

Form container has two purposes. The first one is adjusting the layout of the child form controls in responsive mode.
The second one is collecting the values of the child controls. The second one has no significance
since when the [ElementInternals API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/ElementInternals) is implemented
and the form controls are as fully functional as standard HTML form elements. 
If responsive mode is unnecessary, it is recommended to use the standard `<form>` element.

The Radio component is intended to select a single option from a set of options.
It is designed to be used together with the [Radio Group](/components/radio-group) component.
For a large number of options, the [Single Select](/components/single-select) is recommended.

## Horizontal layout

Default layout is horizontal.

<Demo>

  <Fragment slot="html">

      <vscode-radio label="Dolor" name="horizontal-example"></vscode-radio>
    </vscode-radio-group>
    ```
  </Fragment>
</Demo>

import Demo from "@components/Demo.astro"; import PageSwitcher from "@components/PageSwitcher.astro"; import Imports from "@components/examples/table/Imports.astro"; import BasicExample from "@components/examples/table/BasicExample.astro"; import ScrollableExample from "@components/examples/table/ScrollableExample.astro"; import ResponsiveExample from "@components/examples/table/ResponsiveExample.astro"; import ResizableColumnsExample from "@components/examples/table/ResizableColumnsExample.astro"; import ComplexContentExample from "@components/examples/table/ComplexContentExample.astro"; The unique feature of the Table component, as compared to the standard table element, is its fixed header and resizable columns. ## Basic example ```html First name Last name Email Vincenza Lindgren Delia21@yahoo.com Clark Breitenberg Nat_Moore@gmail.com Fiona Wintheiser Asa30@gmail.com ``` ## Scrollable body If the table is assigned a fixed height and the content exceeds the table's height, the content will become scrollable. ```html First name Last name Vincenza Lindgren ... ``` ## Responsive layout The table switch to compact layout mode when its narrower than the set breakpoint. ```html First name Last name Vincenza Lindgren ... ``` ## Resizable columns ```html First name Last name Vincenza Lindgren ... ``` ## Delayed resizing ```html First name Last name Vincenza Lindgren ... ``` ## Complex content It is also suitable for displaying large amounts of data and complex content. ```html Profile First name Last name Email Introduction
CD

import Demo from "@components/Demo.astro"; import Imports from "@components/examples/forms/Imports.astro"; import BasicFormExample from "@components/examples/forms/BasicFormExample.astro"; import FormDataExample from "@components/examples/forms/FormDataExample.astro"; import BuiltInValidation from "@components/examples/forms/BuiltInValidation.astro"; Form controls in VSCode Elements are designed to be used like standard HTML form elements. The following components can serve as fully functional form controls: - [Button](/components/button) - [Single Select](/components/single-select) - [Multi Select](/components/multi-select) - [Textfield](/components/textfield) - [Textarea](/components/textarea) - [Radio](/components/radio) - [Checkbox](/components/checkbox) ## Basic example Form controls in VSCode Elements work just like native form controls without requiring additional JavaScript. ```html
Search query: Search
``` ## Processing form data In a typical Webview-based extension, the form data is usually submitted in the background without reloading the page. In certain scenarios, it might not be submitted at all. In such cases, the [FormData](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/FormData) interface can be utilized to access the form data. ```html
Title Category Page Article Blog Post Body Submit 

    

    ```
  
  
    ```javascript
    const form = document.getElementById("form1");
    let output = document.getElementById("form1-output");

    form.addEventListener("submit", (ev) => {
      ev.preventDefault();

      const fd = new FormData(form);
      let out = "";

      for (let [name, value] of fd) {
        out += `${name}: ${value}\n`;
      }

      output.innerHTML = out;
    });
    ```

  


## Built-in form validation

VSCode Elements supports the [HTML form validation features](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/Forms/Form_validation#using_built-in_form_validation) built into browsers.
The example below demonstrates how the MDN form validation [sample application](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/Forms/Form_validation#full_example) is re-implemented using
VSCode Elements form controls.


  
  
    ```html
    

      
        Do you have a driver's license?
        
          
          
        
      
      
        Age
        
      
      
        What's your favorite fruit?
        
          Banana
          Cherry
          Apple
          Strawberry
          Lemon
          Orange
        
      
      
        What's your email address?
        
      
      
        Leave a short message
        
      
      
        Submit
      
      

    

    ```
  
  
    ```javascript
      const form = document.getElementById("form2");
      let output = document.getElementById("form2-output");

      form.addEventListener("submit", (ev) => {
        ev.preventDefault();

        const fd = new FormData(form);
        let out = "";

        for (let [name, value] of fd) {
          out += `${name}: ${value}\n`;
        }

        output.innerHTML = out;
      });
    ```

import { Badge } from "@astrojs/starlight/components"; import { Aside } from "@astrojs/starlight/components"; ## What is VSCode Elements? The "webview API" enables extensions to build entirely customizable views within Visual Studio Code. While the VSCode API grants access to different UI elements, none of these UI widgets are functional in the "webview." VSCode Elements addresses this by re-implementing these UI controls as web components (aka custom elements), and introducing some new ones. This allows for the creation of user interfaces that look like the native user interface of VSCode. :::note The appearance of components provided by VSCode Elements depends on the presence of hundreds of CSS variables and default styles supplied by the VSCode Webview. The [Webview Playground](https://github.com/vscode-elements/webview-playground) was created to emulate this environment during development. ::: ## You may not need VSCode Elements If you prefer traditional HTML and CSS over JavaScript, or if you'd rather avoid adding a new dependency, consider checking out the [VSCode Elements Lite](https://vscode-elements.github.io/elements-lite) project. It offers a collection of HTML and CSS snippets that, in many cases, are perfectly suitable. This approach is both simple and robust. ## Installation You can access the library as NPM package: ```bash npm i @vscode-elements/elements ``` ### Including the bundled version This is the most straightforward method, and while it may not be the most optimized, it gets the job done. ```html ``` ### Importing only necessary components ```typescript import "@vscode-elements/elements/dist/vscode-button/index.js"; ``` ## Usage The imported components will be automatically registered. Once registered, Vscode Elements can be used like standard HTML elements. A standard default view can be provided using the `:defined()` pseudo-class until the element is registered. ```css vscode-buttton:not(:defined) { display: inline-block; height: 26px; visibility: hidden; width: 100px; } ``` ### Properties and attributes Custom elements are configurable through properties and attributes. Properties used in JavaScript while attributes are used in HTML. An example of using a property: ```javascript const badge = document.querySelector("vscode-badge"); badge.variant = "activity-bar-counter"; ``` An attribute example ```html ``` The attribute name may differs from the property name. In the API documentation, the attribute corresponding to the property is always indicated if it exists. #### Attribute and property reflection Property reflection means that the related attribute will be synchronized when the property is changed. When a property is reflected it will be indicated with the badge in the API documentation. ### Methods Methods are callable functions on the element instances. ```javascript const textfield = document.querySelector("vscode-textfield"); textfield.reportValidity(); ``` ### Events Most of the components dispatch events. ```javascript const tabs = document.querySelector("vscode-tabs"); tabs.addEventListener("vsc-tabs-select", () => { console.log("A tab has been selected."); }); ``` Most of the components use native events if possible. When a component has a custom event, the event is exported as a TypeScript type. All exported events are descendants of the `CustomEvent` class. ```typescript import type { VscTabsSelectEvent } from "@vscode-elements/elements/dist/vscode-tabs/vscode-tabs"; ``` ### Slots Slots are used to accept HTML content. The default slot, which is the content between the HTML tags, is the most common slot: ```html Click here ``` Many components have named slots. In the following example the badge component is placed in the `decorations` slot. ```html 'slot="decorations"' 99

Suspendisse potenti. Maecenas eu egestas metus. Nulla eget placerat mi, et efficitur augue.

``` ### Custom CSS properties The appearance of VSCode elements can be configured using custom CSS properties. These variables are provided by VSCode, and in most cases, it is not recommended to change them manually, although they can be modified if necessary. ```css vscode-button { --vscode-button-hoverBackground: red; } ```
